text:
I just asked my psychiatrist father about what his thoughts are-- he made the most interesting observation:

Psychiatrists and psychologists have identified a facet of cognitive behaviour called *reality-testing*, which is the ability for a human being to "measure the validity of a proposition or idea against a processed understanding of the way that the world works". The key component of *diagnose-able delusion* in my father's field is _the loss of reality-testing_, which describes the state of an individual who holds a delusion which is intractable against evidence to the contrary or logical argument.

I told my dad about modelling conspiracy theory as "viral thought" and leveraging the established mathematics in epidemiology. I also mentioned that I was a little unsure of the perfectness of the parallel because epidemiological models strongly implicitly depend upon the presence of an "immune system"-- there's a defense against infection which is sure to play a strong role in dynamics. In response he noted that reality-testing constitutes a sort of immune system in this analogy-- a fantastic contribution! A person's innate ability to resist an infectious thought (a delusion) is at least significantly comprised of their ability to rationalize against it.

We may approximately model those who are susceptible to infection by viral thought or conspiracy as "immuno-compromised" individuals in an epidemiological network.
